Untuk belajari lebih banyak tentang Village Banking di Wikipedia, mohon kunjungi website ini: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Village_Banking.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: An's Group

texts.en:
A. An T. D. is 27 years-old. She is married with two children. She lives in Luc Canh village, Dong Anh district, Ha Noi. She is a farmer and also sells vegetables in the market. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She felt happy when she joined Kiva partner SEDA because she can save money every week. She has been with SEDA for three years and always repays her loans punctually. She is a group leader. In this credit cycL., she repuests a loan of 5,014,000 VND in order to expand her business.

There are two other members in her group.  Hien T. N. is 24 years-old and a pig breeder.  She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy food for pigs.   Dao T. L. is 29 years-old and she wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Nai

texts.en: Mrs. C., 39, is a married woman living in Phnom Penh. She is a crop grower and a good homemaker who currently stays at home to care for her children and do housework. She has three kids: two are studying and also work; another one is no longer in school and helps her planting crops. She has a life partner in her husband who assists with her on the farm. C. is taking out her loan to purchase different kinds of fruits to sell for Khmer New Years. This will provide C. with additional income.

loans.use: To purchase fruit.

loans.name: Lot

texts.en: Mrs Lot S., 43, is a local farmer and lives with her husband and three teenage children. She became a crop grower in 1995, a skill she learned from her grandmother. Three of her children are students and work with her on the farm when they are not studying. Her husband, Mr. Long Rin, works with her in the farm field. Lot S. will be using her loan to add to her savings in order to buy a used vehicle to provide transportation for her family.

loans.use: To buy a used vehicle.

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Mrs. Men K. is a 48 year-old, married woman who resides in a district of Phnom Penh city in Cambodia. She sells pork to earn a living. She has had this job for years. She has a life partner in her husband who is a chef for wedding parties. The couple is blessed with six children: three are married and three are unmarried. To help be responsible for the family, three of the children are working at different jobs. Men K. is applying for a loan to improve the financial capital of her pork sale business.

loans.use: To provide additional capital

loans.name: Nhel

texts.en: Mrs. S. is thirty-five years old and a mother of two children.  Both are enrolled in school and also help her business when they are free. She was married but divorced her husband. To earn a living, S. plants flowers that she sells for ceremonies. Also, she buys additional flowers to better meet the needs of her valued customers when she does not have sufficient flowers to sell.  On Khmer New Year, almost Cambodians need flowers for ceremonies. S. is looking for capital to order and buy flowers to sell at a profit.

loans.use: To buy flowers.

loans.name: Marianita

texts.en:
Marianita P. is from the village of Southwestern. She is 38 years-old and married with five adult children. To make a living, Marianita sells ready-to-wear items. Through this activity she is able to earn a monthly net income of about to 1,600.00. She has been doing her business for more than two years.

In 2001, Marianita joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marianita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business . Marianita is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new stock. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Marianita from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mrs. Uk B., 45, sells firewood and charcoal that she buys from people living in the forest area. She lives with her husband and three children. She started her business in 2002. To help resolve the financial difficulties of the family, her eldest daughter works as a garment employee. Uk B. and her husband leave home to buy chopped-wood and charcoal and sell them by using a vehicle with an attached trailer. Recently, Uk B.’s vehicle broke while they were using it and this has affected her business and income. Therefore, Uk B. is asking for a loan to repair the broken vehicle. Any leftover money, Uk B. will use for additional business capital.

loans.use: To repair the broken vehicle.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick O. I. is 50 years of age, married and the father of five children who are dependent on him. He lives in Nambale, Busia District. He runs a brick making business which he started in September 2009 as a source of income generation. Before this he was employed as an electrician in one of the local businesses.

Fredrick makes his stock twice a month and sells it in the surrounding villages. He would like a loan of Kshs. 30,000 which he says he will invest in the brick making business by employing new labor and increasing his production base. His future dream is to buy a vehicle for the business.

loans.use: To expand a brick making business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel B. is from the village of San isidro Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Raquel owns and operates a business venture running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of her business' income comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Raquel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month through these activities.

In 2008, Raquel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raquel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Raquel has now requested a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Raquel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this loan to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Roeun

texts.en: Mrs. N. is a 46-year-old married woman. She works very hard as a dried-clam seller in her village, and typically earns around $3 per day. She has four children: two are married and live separately, another two are single. She has another financial earner in her husband who is a chef for local weddings. N. has a son who is jobless. She would like to help him find a suitable job but she has not been able to do it, because she lacks money. N. decided to seek a Kiva loan through HKL project. She will use the loan to buy a motorcycle which will enable her son use to provide a taxi service.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle which will enable her son use to provide a taxi service.

loans.name: Alleluya Group

texts.fr:
Amani M. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Alleluya ,qui lève la main droite sur la photo, cliente de l’IMF Hekima au 4e cycle, âgée de 41 ans, mère de 8 enfant s dont 6 vont  à l’école et  2 autres sont encore gosses. Son mari est Etudiant à l’université à Goma.
Elle a commencé son petit commerce général de divers  avec son fond propre. Son capital initial était de 80$ appuyé par le crédit de l’IMF Hekima. Elle s’installe régulièrement dans le petit marché du quartier localement  surnommé Trois paillotes - Axe Katindo où elle vend ses produits divers Fanta, farine, savon de lessive Omo, huille , etc. Elle vend également du pétrole à  domicile pour augmenter ses revenus.  
Amani M.  souhaite obtenir plus des crédits pour accroitre son chiffre d’affaire et  construire une maison  pour sa famille. 
Elle rémércie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle recoit sans aucune garantie materielle car grace à ces crédits elle parvient  à se payer des unstensils de cuisine et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille, et ses enfants étudient confortablement.
Le groupe Alleluya est composé de 15 membres, toutes femmes.
texts.en:
Amani M. is the president of the Alleluya borrowing group, and it is her raising her right hand on the photo. She is a customer of IMF Hekima (4th cycle), 41 years old and mother to eight children, six of whom go to school, the other two being small children still. Her husband is a student at the university in Goma. She began her small diverse business with her own funds. Her initial capital was $80, backed up by a loan from IMF Hekima. She sets herself up in the small market in her neighborhood with the local nickname of "Trois Paillottes - Axe Katindo", where she sells her various products: Fanta, flour, Omo washing powder, oil etc.. She also sells kerosene at home in order to boost her income. Amani M. would like to obtain more loans in order to increase her turnover and build a house for her family. She is grateful to IMF Hekima for the loans she is granted without any material guarantee, since thanks to these loans she is able to pay for kitchen utensils and provide for the needs of her family; her children are able to study comfortably. The Alleluya group is made up of 15 members, all women.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Two bags of cassava flour, one bag of sugar, one container of Rina oil, one box of salt, one bag of beans

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mien's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mien P. has been recruited to be the leader of this group by the other borrowers. She is 38, married, and the mother of five children. Four of her children are students.  The other is no longer in school and is working as a porter. Mien P. currently earns her daily living by working as a carrying laborer in the local market, earning $2 each day. Her husband is also a porter in the same the market. The family’s living conditions are not comfortable because their house needs repairs.  Mien P. is seeking a loan to make some improvements to her house.

The other borrowers who have joined this loan group are: Am P., a grocery seller who is seeking a loan to run her business more smoothly; Hoat N., a fish porter who needs a loan to decorate her old house; and Ren K., who is asking for a loan to mend her house.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Tweyambe Group Of Jinja

texts.en:
N. Rebecca is a 45-year-old hardworking mother of nine children. For eight years, she has incorporated the selling of fish and crafts as a means of earning income to support herself and her family. Inadequate capital to fully develop her business has been a major long drawn-out problem ever since she began.

In Wairasa, Jinja district, where Rebecca operates from, she has earned a reputation as a forthright businesswoman who clients can rely on. As a positive consequence, her profits have been increasing as manifested by the 20,000 shillings she earns on a weekly basis.

Rebecca is anticipating making further progress in her business endeavors on the acquisition of this loan. With this loan, she says wants to rejuvenate her business by purchasing more fresh fish supplies every week. She also wants to restock the crafts section in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh fish supplies and more crafts to sell

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane P. is from the village of  Camp Phillips Bukidnon. She is 34 years old and married, with 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane makes and sells food.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for more than 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities. Mary Jane's husband contributes to the family's income by providing motorcycle transport to passengers from their village (photo taken with her husband's motorcycle).

In 2009, Mary Jane joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mary Jane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Đức's Group

texts.en: Đức N. Thị (20201020084) is a 47-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. She is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is N. xá -02 (2). Đức is married and has three adult children. She operates a business making and selling food, selling rice products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 2,800,000 VND a month. In 2010, Đức joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. The loan will be her first from SEDA. Đức plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. N. Thị (20201020084) là 47 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. Đức là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Đức thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 2 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Đức kiếm được khoảng 2.800.000 VND. Đức đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ SEDA. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.496.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. N. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Cora's Group

texts.en: Cora L. is from the village of Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old and is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Cora is married and has four adult children. She owns and operates a business raising and selling pigs. She has been engaged in her business for over thirteen years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month. In 2009, Cora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the standard of living of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her pigs

loans.use: School fees

loans.name: Beth

texts.en: Beth E. is from the village of Camp Phillips, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 41 years old, is widowed, and has six school-aged children. Beth owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling processed food like longganisa (pork sausage flavored with indigenous spices), hotdogs and more in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Beth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Beth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en: Dulce B. is from the village of Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Dulce is engaged in selling household items and through this activity she is able to earn a monthly net income of 1,300 PHP. In 2004, Dulce joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Dulce is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for her store. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. loans.name: Igorora Tukore Association, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
This 48-year-old female, K. Agnes, is hardworking and dedicated to her banana plantation enterprise that she has run for over ten years. This has earned her a profit of 200,000 Ugandan shillings monthly which has helped in providing basic needs for her six children.

This loan will be an incentive for Agnes to purchase farm tools like hoes and fertilizer and to modernize her plantation to improve on the banana crop which is commonly used by customers for making local dishes. This will increase Agnes’s sales revenue and enable her to pay her daily bills including her children’s school fees.

Agnes belongs to a group that hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase hoes, mulches  and fertilizer for her banana plantation

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen is a 30-year-old single lady who runs a hairdressing and beauty salon to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years and has three employees. She has a good customer base due to her good customer-care skills.

Aileen saves her money with her group in Faulu Kenya called diamond which guarantees loans to its members. She hopes to grow her business and venture into many other businesses in the future.

Aileen has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of braids and hair chemicals.

Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 5. T. Thị Hương (20203050096) là 19 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất. 6. N. Thị Hiền (20203050097) là 24 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Uyanga

texts.en:
Uyanga E. is a 39-year-old woman.  She lives in the town of Ulaanbaatar.  She is married and does not have any children.  To make a living, Uyanga owns and operates a jewelry business.  Uyanga has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,150,000 Tugrug a month.

Uyanga joined Credit Mongol LLC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She is requesting a loan of 1,700,000 Tugrug.  This loan, her first from Credit Mongol LLC, will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings.  Uyanga plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her jewelry business.

About Credit Mongol:
Credit Mongol’s mission is to contribute to the prosperity of Mongols by providing diversified financial services to micro and SME clients and to become the best performing company in micro and SME financing in Mongolia.

loans.use: To expand her jewelry business

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita U. and her family are very much thankful to ASHI. Because of her membership, she has able to access loans she used to finance a business from its start and through its growth. Her husband’s fishing business started very small. Eventually, through their consecutive and increasing amount of loan received through ASHI, it has grown because they were able to purchase two fishing motorboats.

Lolita is the one who sells the fish to the fish vendors in the town’s public market and the proceeds of her business are used to improve the lives of her family and support the education of her three children. Unfortunately, Lolita’s children didn’t want to pursue their education in college. Lolita is unhappy with their decision but she has to respect her children’s decision to help her in growing her business and making it stable and profitable.

With that, through the loan she is requesting, she plans to purchase another fishing boat to be managed by her eldest child who is now 24 years old. Lolita and her two daughters (18 and 19 years old) will be helping each other to sell their fish and record the family cash flow.

Someday, Lolita wishes her business will become stable and sustainable whereby it generates employment. She wants to help other people in their community have their own source of income through her family business.

loans.use: To purchase another fishing motorboat for the family business

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice, age 33, sells waste garments to earn a living and to keep the environment clean. She buys waste garments from a factory and sells them to retailers in the local market for recycling. She has been in the business since 2008 and hopes to increase her profits in the future. She has been saving her money with her group in Faulu Kenya called 'Weep Not,' which guarantees loans to its members. She has requested a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more garments and a sewing machine.

loans.use: To add stock of waste garments and buy a sewing machine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla R. is from the village of Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Perla is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Perla sells charcoal products in the local community. Perla has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Perla joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Perla has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Perla is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional charcoal products to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Perla from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal products to sell

loans.name: Hung

texts.en:
Hung D. L. is a 30-year-old man with a wife and two young children. Hung is a farmer. For the past five years, he has also been a carpenter. His monthly income is approximately 4,000,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND). He has participated in SEDA's micro-financing program since 2008 and has always met his repayment obligations on time. In his last loan, Hung borrowed 4,704,000 VND. 

Hung is now seeking 8,288,000 VND in order to purchase wood to make wooden household furnishings.

loans.use: To purchase wood to make wooden household furnishings

loans.name: Arnel

texts.en:
Arnel D., age 30, is from the village of Poblacion Sapang Dalaga. He is married and has three small children. To make a living, Arnel is engaged in the retail sector, particularly in the selling of household items. Through this activity, he is able to earn a monthly net income amounting to 5,000.00. 

In 2005, Arnel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. He wanted to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Arnel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for his business. Arnel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new stocks for his store. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Arnel from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase household items to offer for sale in his store

loans.name: Portia

texts.en:
Portia P., age 55, is from the village of Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has four grown children. To make a living, Portia is engaged in the agriculture sector, particularly in the planting of rice. Through this activity, she is able to earn a monthly net income amounting to 5,000.00. 

In 2003, Portia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Portia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business . Portia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm supplies. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Portia from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna D. is from the village of Solinog, Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old, married and blessed with four adult-aged children. She is a businesswoman, engaged in food vending. Through this activity she's able to generate a monthly net income of 10,000 Philippine pesos.

In 2008, Myrna joined Kiva field partner PMPC to gain access to the financial services of the co-op which she hoped would help improve her business. She has successfully repaid her previous loan with PMPC on time. Myrna is requesting another loan in the amount of 15,000 Philippine pesos in order to expand her business. As Myrna was able to repay her previous loan, she was allowed to borrow again and is now on her 9th loan availment.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for its field partner PMPC to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for a food vending business.

loans.name: Samwel Matunke

texts.en:
Samwel is a farmer and he has been doing this for the last twenty years. His farm is in a productive area and most of his customers are wholesalers from the capital city (Nairobi), who come to buy his produce and then sell to the city residents.

He learned about KADET through awareness raised by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan which he is planning to use to buy a new species of potato called sangi which, research has proved, can do very well in his area and have more yields. He also wishes to buy ten sheep for fattening and to later sell to accumulate more capital for large scale farming.

He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for the farm produce. His hopes to become a large scale farmer and have his own farm machinery in future. Samwel is a hard-working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy a new species of potato called sangi and ten sheep for fattening.

loans.name: Lita

texts.en: Married with children who go to school, 56-year-old Lita runs a sari-sari store at her house. She works hard to be able to provide for her family and sustain her children’s education. She also sought the help of CEVI, a microfinance organization in the Philippines, to gain financial support for her business. She says that its program is really helpful to entrepreneurs like her who need financial assistance. Lita is now applying for a loan of Php18,000, which she will use to acquire vinegar, sugar and other merchandise she sells in her store.

loans.use: Additional inventory

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn, who is married to Arturo, is 40 years old and has two children, both in college now. She sells furniture to earn a living. She and her husband both work hard to be able to have their two children finish college. She says that it is not that easy because school fees increase every year. Hoping for her furniture business to prosper, Marilyn is requesting a loan of Php12,000 from CEVI to buy wood, nails and other raw materials she needs for making furniture.

loans.use: Raw materials

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad loves cooking. In 2005, she decided to earn a living out of her passion. She cooked viands (tasty dishes) and started selling first to her neighbors. When she heard of CEVI, she immediately joined to gain financial support for her business. She was happy because she was able to buy more ingredients and was able to cook more.

Natividad is now requesting to borrow 10,000 Philippine pesos. She will use it to buy vegetables and other ingredients she needs for her viands. This loan will help sustain her business.

loans.use: Ingredients

loans.name: Fe Estacoja's Group

texts.en:
Fe E., from the village of Tubod, Aloran Misamis Occidental, is the 35-year-old leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Fe E.'s Group.

Fe , who is married and has three school-aged children, owns and operates a sari-sari store selling a variety of products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2005, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan from PMPC, Fe is requesting a new loan, her 12th, of 14999 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing engages in a rechargeable cellphone cards business and also sells drinks. With these businesses she makes her living in Benin City, Nigeria.

Blessing wants to stock her store with more rechargeable phone cards to attract more customers and improve on her sales. She is requesting a loan of NGN 40,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and drinks to sell as this will go a long way towards increasing her income.

Blessing is 28 years old and is married with two children, 4 and 7 years old. She appreciate all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable cellphone cards and drinks to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita P. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 32 years old and single. To make a living, Teresita  sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month. 

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in the business. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tuan

texts.en: Tuan D. N. is 29-years old and married with two young children. He has been a carpenter for the past five years. In this line of work, he earns approximately 4,000,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND) per month. Tuan has participated in SEDA's microfinancing program since 2008. In the last term, he borrowed 4,704,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount. In this loan cycle, Tuan would like to borrow 8,288,000 VND in order to purchase additional wood supplies in order to manufacture his furniture products.

loans.use: to purchase wood to manufacture his furniture products.

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu A. is from the village of Pagalungan, Cagayan de  oro City. She is 28 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Marichu sells seafood products including fish and shrimp. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marichu joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marichu is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marichu from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Friba Eqbal Group

texts.en: Najeba is the daughter of M., the leader of the four-person Friba Eqbal group. She is married and the mother of four children. They live in Kabul, Afghanistan. She wants to take a loan for her son who is single and lives at home. He has a general store and the whole family benefits from the income it generates so he wants to enlarge it. His mother, Najeba, has requested a loan for her son. She is happy that she has got this chance to help his progress.

loans.use: to increase his  inventory

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is 33 years old and married with two children who go to school. She sells used clothes in Kitengela market in Nairobi to earn a living. She was previously employed but needed more money and so started her own business. Catherine is a hard-working lady who does her household chores at the same time as running the business. She has been saving part of her profits with her group in Faulu Kenya, called Mlachake, which guarantees loans to its members. She has requested a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of used clothes for sale and hopes to grow her business and, in the future, to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To add to stock of used clothing for sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Melecia C. is from the village of Pagalungan, Cgayan de Oro City. She is 46 years old and married with eight school-aged children. To make a living, Melecia sells firewood. Melecia has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month. 

In 2009, Melecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melecia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Melecia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Melecia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sagher Qashang Group

texts.en: Nekbakht is the daughter of E., the leader of the Sagher Qashang group. She lives in district six, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has six children. She has responsibility for all the members of her household. Her son has a bakery near his house and needs some money. So his mother (Nekbakht) has requested a loan so he can buy more wood and other necessary things for his bakery as he wants to increase his business. She is very thankful to Kiva lenders and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: to buy more wood for his bakery

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 23-year-old man who is married to a farmer. He has sold mobile phone accessories for three years and has one employee. He also helps his wife with the farming. He joined a group called Woni Asro  so as to access loans. With this group, he saves his money weekly. He has requested a loan of Kes.20,000 to buy cell phone batteries, cables and cell phone airtime cards. He hopes to start importing his stock in the future.

loans.use: To buy cell phone batteries, cables and cell phone air-time cards

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Xuan

texts.en: Xuan T. N. is a 29-year old woman with a husband and three children in elementary school. Her main occupation is raising livestock such as pigs and growing rice. She earns approximately 3,000,500 Vietnamese Dong (VND) per month. Xuan has participated in SEDA's lending program since 2009 and has always repaid her loans on time. In the last loan term,  Xuan borrowed 5,152,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 8,288,000 VND in order to repair her pig-pens and to purchase additional pigs to raise.

loans.use: in order to repair her pig-pens and to buy additional pigs to raise.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a 45-year-old widow with six children. She has been selling clothes for the past six years and is a member of a group of young entrepreneurs under Faulu Kenya. This group has helped her get new business ideas and has even guaranteed a loan which she took out from Faulu Kenya. Josephine has requested a loan of Kes.20,000 to buy women's clothes to sell. She is a hard-working lady who hopes to build her own house in the future.

loans.use: To buy women's clothes to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Henry is a hardworking married man with two children who are in school.  To earn a living, for the past six years he has been conducting a business whereby he uses scrap metals to make spoons, metal boxes and cooking pans, a very profitable enterprise though the competition is stiff due to changing technology.  He was previously employed in the same kind of business before he saved enough money to start his own.  He saves part of his earnings with his group in Faulu Kenya called Genesis, which guarantees loans to its members. He is now requesting a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add a stock of scrap metals. Henry hopes to open a manufacturing company and improve his living standards in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of scap metal to make more cooking pans, metal boxes and spoons.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en: Kadiatu K. lives in Ogoo farm with her husband and three daughters, two in primary school and one in nursery school.  Kadiatu, 26, has a shop where she sells drinks and slippers, a business she has operated for 10 years now. She is a LAPO, SL client and has taken three previous loans, all used to expand her business, pay her children's school fees, and help feed her family.  Kadiatu now needs a new loan of 2,000,000 Leones to buy baby clothes to add to her shop inventory.

loans.use: To purchase baby clothes, slippers and drinks for her shop

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard is twenty-nine years old and has two children in school. He has been selling clothes for five years and has one employee. He has been a member of Faulu Kenya under a group called Mareba where he saves his money weekly. He has been attending seminars offered by Faulu Kenya that have made him more aggressive in his business. He wants to take out his first loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya, and he has been guaranteed by his group members. He plans to use this loan to increase his stock of clothes to sell. Bernard is a very hardworking man who hopes to expand his business into a wholesale shop to improve his profit margins and standard of living.

loans.use: To buy clothes for sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adama

texts.en: Adama B. is twenty-eight years old. She is married and has five children: two girls and three boys.The eldest child is in secondary school, the middle three are in primary school, and the youngest is in nursery school.Her husband work as a security guard in one of the small firms in Sierra Leone. Adama and her family live in Ogoo farm where she has a shop selling food. She has been a client of LAPO Sierra Leone for quite sometime now, and she has taken three previous loans. With the money from her past loans, she was able to complete the building of her shop, where she sells her goods now, and to pay the school fees for her children. Adama needs a loan of 3,000,000 SLL to invest in her business; she hopes the loan will enable her to earn more profits that will help her and her entire family.

loans.use: This loan will be used to invest in her business selling food

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en:
N. Betty is a single mother of one child and four helpless dependents. She has operated a bar business for seven years, earning her a profit of 100,000 Ugandan shillings. This bar is strategically located in Kibaati, Mubende District, with highly esteemed customer care and hygiene, thus pulling in a good number of customers.

With this loan, Betty hopes to purchase more stock; that is: beers, soft drinks like sodas, and wines in order to meet the increasing demand from her customers. This will fetch her more profits, enable her to sustain her family needs, and motivate her to go for her dream of starting up a beer depot.
 
Betty belongs to a group of thirteen members who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan because they want to access the future successfully.

loans.use: To purchase more beers, wine and sodas for her bar business

loans.name: Gull-E-Lala Group

texts.en: Nasrin J. is thirty-nine years old and the leader of Gull-E-Lala group. Nasrin is married and has four children. She lives in the 7th district in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a very hardworking women and she is honest. She is responsible for all of the members of her house. She is a tailor and she sews different kinds of pillows. She has requested a loan to help increase her business and buy the materials she needs to do her tailoring. She thanks the Kiva lenders a lot.

loans.use: To buy materials she needs to do her tailoring

loans.name: Hasanatu

texts.en: Hasanatu S. is 40 years old,married with two children, both girls. One is in primary school and the last is in nursery school. Hasanatu lives in Ogoo Farm with her family, where she has a  provision shop.She has taken two previous loans from LAPO,SL, with which she purchased more provisions into her shop.She is asking for a loan of 1,000,000 Leones to enable her grow in business.

loans.use: This loan will be used to buy food and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en: Aminata B. is fifty years old and married with six children: she has four sons and two daughters. Her three eldest children are already out of school; of the youngest three children, one is in college, one is in primary school, and the youngest is in nursery school. Aminata lives with her family in Ogoo farm. She has a shop very close to her house where she sells beverages and engine oil. Aminata has been in this business for ten years. She joined LAPO Sierra Leone over a year ago and has taken out three previous loans. She used her past loans to expand her business, and she is seeking a loan of 2,000,000 SLL to help grow her busness and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: This loan will be use to purchase beverages and engine oil for sale.

loans.name: Kyogaya Women's Group Of Jinja

texts.en:
N. Betty has been operating her tailoring and bar business in Wakalenge, Jinja, for the last twenty-five years. Her good customer care attributes have been her stock in trade over these years. The 42-year-old happily married mother of six is gleeful at the success she has registered, despite her earlier reservations.

Before venturing into her current business, Betty was employed by a high-profile textile factory. It is from here that she learnt her seamstress skills. She points out that the education of her children is a milestone she always cherished to achieve. In this time of running her own business she has minimally broken the back of that dream.

With this loan Betty wants to buy more drinks for her bar and also buy sewing machines.

loans.use: To purchase new sewing machines and drinks for her bar business

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en: Mariama J. is fifty years old and married with five children; she has four sons and one daughter. Her eldest child is in secondary school, and the others are in primary school. Her husband is a driver. They live in Laka, where she has a shop selling provisions including beverages and biscuits. Mariama has been in this business for fifteen years. She joined LAPO Sierra Leone over a year ago, and she has taken three previous loans to expand her busness. She pays the school fees for her children with her profit. Now she is asking LAPO Sierra Leone with the help of Kiva lenders to loan her 2,000,000 SLL so she can expand her business.

loans.use: This loan will be use to purchase bags of water, other beverages, and biscuits.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is forty-four years old and married with four children. She has been running a salon at Kawangware in Nairobi to earn a living. She has been in this business for three years and has three employees. Her husband, who is employed, has given her much support in the business. She appreciates Faulu Kenya for the training they offered her because she acquired business-management skills. She has high hopes of expanding her business since she can access loans, and this will be her first loan. She dreams of opening outlets and improving her standard of living in the future. She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to buy hair chemicals and synthetic hair for use in her salon.

loans.use: To buy hair chemicals and synthetic hair for use in her salon

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en: Isatu B. is married with four children; she has one son and three daughters. The two eldest children are in secondary school and the younger two are in primary school. Her husband is a businessman, who does the same type of business as she does. They live in Laka, where she has a provisions shop. She has been in this business for twenty years, and she has taken one previous loan from LAPO Sierra Leone. Isatu is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 SLL to enable her to add to her business and assist her family.

loans.use: This loan will be used to buy provisions for sale.

loans.name: Hawanatu

texts.en: Hawanatu W. has been a client of LAPO Sierra Leone for almost two years now, and she has taken three previous loans. She used the previous loans to expand her shop. Hawanatu is forty-five years old and married with eight children; she has four sons and four daughters. Her eldest child is in college, two are in secondary school, and the younger five are in primary school. Hawanatu's husband is a building contractor, and they live in Laka where she has a building-material shop. Hawanatu is asking for a loan of 3,000,0000 SLL to enable her buy more of items for sale.

loans.use: This loan will be used to purchase building materials for sale.

loans.name: Quraishi Group

texts.en: K. Abdulsaboor, the son of K. M. Z., is the 26-year-old leader of the Quraishi group.  Married and the father of two children, K. lives in Kabul, Afghanistan where he has operated a photo shop for more than two years. He has already successfully completed his first loan cycle loan and expanded his business. Still, he wants to further expand his business and so now is requesting his second loan to enlarge his shop in order to attract more customers and make a better income to help his family.  K. is happy with the process of small loans offered in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Duoc

texts.en:
Duoc T. N. is 39 years old and is married with three children. She sells sea fish in the market. In this line of work, she earns approximately 4,000,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND) per month. 

Duoc has participated in SEDA's microfinancing program since 2003. In the last term, she borrowed 6,322,000 VND and has completely repaid this amount. 

In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her fish-selling business

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a 30-year-old lady who has been selling tomatoes, onions, and fruit for two years in a very competitive environment.  Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has been motivated to work hard in her business.  She belongs to a group called Diamond Women within Faulu Kenya, which has guaranteed her a loan of KES 20,000.  

Flora is a hardworking and visionary lady who hopes to enlarge her business so as to become financially stable.  She plans to use this loan to buy more tomatoes and onions for sale.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes and onions for resale

loans.name: Kadie

texts.en:
Kadie is 30 years old, and married with six children--a girl and five boys--four of whom are in primary school, and two in nursery school.  She owns a shop in Laka, where she sells building materials.

Kadie is a very good member of LAPOSL and has taken three previous loans to expand her shop and assist her husband in paying the children's school fees.  She now needs a loan of SLL 3,000,000 to grow her business and also to help her family.

loans.use: This loan will be used to purchase building materials.

loans.name: Yakka

texts.en:
Yakha D. is 38 years old and happily married to her husband, who is a businessman.  They have two girls in primary school.  She owns a shop selling bicycle parts and building materials. She has been in this business for over 15 years. 

Yakha has been a LAPOSL client for over a year and has taken three previous loans that helped her to expand her business. Yakha used the profit to take care of herself and family.  Now she is seeking a loan of SLL 2,000,000 to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: This loan will be used to buy bicycle parts and building materials.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en:
Cicilia is a 30-year-old married lady with one child.  Her husband is employed as a driver and they both work hard to meet their family’s needs. 

Cicilia is glad to be involved in a group called Neges within Faulu Kenya because she can save money on weekly basis.  She joined this group to easily access financial resources from Faulu Kenya--group members guarantee each other when a member takes out a loan.

For two years, Cicilia has sold second-hand clothes, and she hopes to enlarge the business into a wholesale in the future.  She has requested a loan of KES 20,000 to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Aly

texts.fr:
Monsieur Aly S. est marié à une femme et est père de 6 enfants (3garçons et 3 filles). Il est né vers 1963 à Brimado et  vit dans une famille monogame avec ses enfants et son épouse à Loulouni une des sous préfecture de la préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative  de la république du Mali.
Il  fait le commerce depuis maintenant 10 ans et excelle dans l’achat et la vente de céréales. Expérimenté en raison des années dans le domaine, il le mène avec réussite et est très sollicité. 
Il est à sa première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt,  2 tonnes de maïs. Il s’approvisionne à Loulouni et dans les villages avoisinants auprès des producteurs. Il vend au comptant et souvent à crédit, en gros et en détail, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 80.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il  ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Sikasso ville.
texts.en:
Mr. Aly S. is married and father to six children (three boys and three girls). He was born in 1963 in Brimado and lives in a monogamous family with his children and his wife in Loulouni, one of the sub-prefectures of the prefecture of Kadiolo, the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. He has been in business for ten years now and excels in the purchase and sale of cereals. As a result of the number of years he has worked in this area he is experienced, successful and in great demand. He is on his first loan from the micro-finance institution, Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan he is planning on buying two tons of corn. He gets his supplies in Loulouni and from producers in neighboring villages. He sells for cash and often on credit, wholesale and retail, to a customer base made up of women and men. He envisages making a monthly profit of 80,000 FCFA, of which part will be used to increase his business; he will save the rest because his ambition is to buy a house in Sikasso Town to live in.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Rana Rashid Group

texts.en: WaisM., son of F., is the 32-year-old leader of Rana Rashid Group. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with five children. WaisM. has a small retail shop in the city of Kabul and he needs a loan for his business to become strong so he can help his family in a better way. He requested a loan to enlarge his business and make it progress. He wants to buy necessary materials, complete stock for his shop, and start working hard.

loans.use: To expand his retail shop

loans.name: Hernan

texts.en: To make a living, Hernan R. provides jeep/ jeepney services to local community members. He is 37 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Airport Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. Hernan has been in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. Being a jeepney driver, Hernan has a sari sari store managed by his wife as another source of income. In 2009, Hernan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Hernan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide his service. Hernan is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his third loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap T. (in the photo), age 55, and her husband, Mr. Sophanny Chan, age 50, have been married since 1979 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home, two attend school, one weaves silk at home and the other two work in a garment factory. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sopheap is a silk weaver. Besides her weaving business, she also runs a grocery store in the village. Her husband drives a motor taxi. She is asking for a loan of $800 to purchase silk materials for her and her daughter’s weaving business. She will also use part of her loan to buy grocery items for inventory.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and grocery items for resale

loans.name: Syeed Sakhi

texts.en:
S. Sakhi Dad, son of S. H., is an old man with lots of experience. Although he is uneducated, he has a shop where he sells fresh fruits and vegetables. He has been operating this business for more than 9 years. He works with his family and loves to work hard. 

Therefore, he has a requested an individual loan of 40000 Afghani to buy more fruits and vegetables for his shop. He wants to continue his partnership and encourage other workers to use this loan service. He offers thanks to all lenders, to Kiva and and to AFS in Afghanistan

loans.use: To buy more fresh fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Ghulam Sediq

texts.en:
The man who is in the picture is Ghulam Sediq, the son of G. M.. He is 35 years old and married, and is the father of four children. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a very honest and talented man. He is a high-school math teacher and he is very happy with his whole family.

Ghulam Sediq has a friend whose name is Ajmal Rasooly. Ajmal has a small retail shop in city of Kabul, but he has some problems with his business. He needs a loan of 14000 Afghani to expand his shop and he needs money to invest in his shop more. Therefore, Ghulam Sediq wants to take an individual loan for his friend (Ajmal Rasooly) to start and expand his shop.He wants to purchase sanitary products like, powder, soap and eatable things like,cola,energy driks and so on.
Finally, he would like to thank Kiva, its lenders, and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: for purchasing sanitary products and beverages

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa S. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Teresa is widowed. To make a living, Teresa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where he sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Teresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Teresa's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Sokhna

texts.fr: Sokhna S. est une femme de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DNAKH S. depuis 07 ans et demi et a eu 15 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit qu'elle a toujours bien géré et remboursé à temps. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine, elle va acheter 10 béliers qu'elle va engraisser et revendre au bout de 5 mois. Elle participe financièrement à la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
Sokhna S. is a 43-year old woman who is married and mother to three children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in DNAKH S. for seven and half years and has benefited from 15 consecutive loans, which she has always managed well and repaid on time. She has a sheep fattening business and she is going to buy 10 rams which she will fatten up and resell after five months. She contributes financially to the family expesnes.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her fattening business

loans.name: Fati

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme commerce la vente de charbons de bois et ce depuis 2007, plus tard elle a associé à ce commerce la vente d’ignames, elle demande de WAGES un prêt pour s’approvisionner avec 20 sacs de charbons de bois, des tubercules  et divers.
Elle est célibataire et ce commerce lui permet de subvenir à ses propres besoins
texts.en:
This lady has a business selling charcoal and has been doing this since 2007. Subsequently she complemented this activity with the sale of yams. She is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to get fresh supplies: 20 sacks of charcoal, tubers and other items. She is single and this business allows her to provide for her needs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and yam tubers

loans.name: Dominic Kiguta

texts.en:
Dominic is 33 years old and married to Esther, who is a businesswoman. They are blessed with two children: a son aged four years and a daughter aged two years.

Dominic is a tailor by profession and he has been in the tailoring business for the past six years. He has applied for a loan to purchase fabric for making curtains, since there is high demand for them. He will also use his loan to restock different fabrics, so clients will have a larger selection. He also needs to add a sewing machine and create employment for someone else to help him. With the extra profit expected from the business, he intends to open a tailoring school to train others .
 
Dominic hopes to expand his clothing business and export his own clothes. He describes himself as a hard-working business man who is focused and ambitious.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for curtains and add another sewing machine

loans.name: Senon

texts.en:
Senon G. is from the village of Lumbia in Cagayan de Oro. He is 41 years old. Senon is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Senon owns and operates a specialized retail store where he sells seafood, such as dried fish and shrimp, in the local community. Senon has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Senon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Senon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Senon is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to expand his business. This will be Senon's 3rd loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand his business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: God Gives Group

texts.en:
Annie Z. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Gives. She is married and has 5 children who range from 10 to 20 years old. Annie did not have the opportunity to go school.

For 12 years, Annie has been selling charcoal at the Plank Field in the Redlight Market in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells good and dry charcoal to customers in order to encourage them to continue patronizing her business. Annie started selling with very little cash, but she has now improved. She has a problem because a lot people sell the same goods that she sells, which sometimes makes business bad. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more charcoal to serve customers. Her goal is to expand her business to a better size and to improve the living conditions of her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Annie is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to serve customers.

loans.name: Peter Nduati

texts.en:
Peter is 42 years old and married to Nancy, a farmer. They have three sons, aged 6 years, 10 years and 13 years old.

Peter has been selling chicken for the past seven months. He also has a secondary business selling water to the people in the community with the help of his wife. Peter was introduced to Kadet through marketing outreach done in Thika town. 

He has applied for a loan to buy chickens to sell and to expand his chicken house. With the extra profit generated from the business, he intends to re-invest in his chicken business . 

Peter’s future dreams are to get into the transport business by purchasing a Nissan Matatu. He describes himself as a hard-working business man who is ambitious and visionary and does not lose hope.

loans.use: To buy chickens and expand his poultry house

loans.name: Kindo

texts.en:
Kindo S. is a good member of LAPOSL.  She is 35 years old, married to a businessman, and has three children, two girls and a boy.Two of the children are in primary school and the last one is still a baby.

Kindo sells bags of sachet water and bottles of  pure water on Lumley Street in the centre of Freetown. She has been in this busness for the past nine years and has taken four previous loans With her previous loan, she opened a shop and bought a deep freezer.

Kindo wanted a loan of 3,000,000 Leones to enable her to travel out of Sierra Leone to a neighbouring country to buy more goods so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy sachet water and bottled water

loans.name: Tushubure Hamwe, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
In a certain small Ibanda town is a determined lady, B. Beatrice, a go-getter businesswoman who is a market vendor dealing in general merchandise. This stickler for hard work and also the mother of four, has basked in the checkered career graces of her business for the last five years. With this experience behind her, she has managed to subdue most of the uncertain adversities that have threatened to play havoc with her business.

In a month Beatrice’s business generates her a profit of 250,000 Ugandan shillings. This, to all intents and purposes, is a low figure. What has played into her hands as she operates her business has been her exceptional customer relationship skills.

As it is now, Beatrice is taking a long view with the aim of maximizing her small profits. She figures this loan will come in significantly handy in helping her buy more stock.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Kache

texts.en:
Kache G. is a vegetable farmer in Majaoni in Mombasa. She is 50 years old. She is married to Rashid and they have four children. Kache also sells firewood from her residence, a business that has been in operation for four years now.

This is Kache's second loan from KADET. With the loan money, she intends to purchase more firewood to resell and vegetables for planting. She mainly serves the residents of Majaoni, most of whom are retailers.

She hopes to expand her farming activities and to increase the scale of her firewood supplies.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and vegetables for planting.

loans.name: Memounatou

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère de 3 enfants, en 2003 elle a commencé le commerce de céréales, elle exerce son commerce près du marché local d’agoè logopé, elle s’approvisionne au marché d’Anié. Voulant gonfler son stock de marchandises, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 3 sacs de maïs, 2 sacs de mil et 2 sacs d’haricot.
texts.en:
This lady is married and mother to three children. In 2003 she began selling cereals and she does this near the local market in Agoè Iogopé. She gets her supplies at the market in Anié. As she would like to boost her stock, she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy three bags of corn, two bags of millet and two bags of beans.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou S. est âgée de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DANKH SENE depuis 06 ans et a 12 fois de suite reçu de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine, elle compte acheter 10 moutons qu'elle va emboucher pendant au moins 05 mois avant de les revendre au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires locaux. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer aux différentes charges familiales.
texts.en:
Fatou S. is 48 years old, married and mother to four children who are in her care. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in DANKH SENE for the past six years and has had 12 consecutive loans; she has never had any problems with the repayments. She has a sheep fattening activity and is planning on buying 10 sheep which she will fatten up for five months before reselling them at the local weekly markets. Her profits allow her to contribute to the various family expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop and promote her sheep fattening activity

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia M. is married and has four children. She runs a retail shop in Majaoni, Mombasa where she sells household goods. Her retail shop is one year old and is doing well. 

This loan marks Lydia's second time borrowing from KADET. With the money, Lydia plans to purchase cooking oil, maize flour, and sugar for her shop. Her clients are the area residents of Majaoini.

Lydia hopes to have a really bright future and to open up another business to supplement her income.
