loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadia D. est une femme divorcée de 36 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec un de ses enfants chez son grand frère dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) 
Madame Kadia n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école moderne et s’intéressa très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus. Après avoir tenté plusieurs activités sans succès, elle finit par opter pour le domaine de l’habillement avec l’achat et la vente de bazins.
Avec une expérience de 4 ans, elle maîtrise cette activité et dans laquelle elle est très sollicitée. 
Dans la souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, elle décida de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance. Elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel après avoir correctement remboursé le précédent. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Elle envoie ses articles en République de la Côte d’Ivoire où ils sont vendus, essentiellement au comptant à une clientèle composée de ressortissants Maliens.
Elle envisage réaliser  avec ce prêt, un bénéfice mensuel de 65.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour agrandir  son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia D. is a divorced lady who is 36 years old and mother to two children. She lives with one of her children at her older brother's house in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Kadia did not have the opportunity to attend modern school and became interested at an early age in revenue-generating activities. Having tried out several activities without success, she ended up opting for the clothing business, buying and selling damask fabric. With four years of experience, she now manages this business well and is in great demand. As she is concerned about satisfying her ever increasing customer base, she decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution. She is on her second individual loan having repaid the previous one on time. She gets her supplies from wholesalers in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). She sends her articles to the Republic of the Ivory Coast, where they are sold, mainly for cash to a customer base made up of Malian nationals. With this loan she envisages making a monthly profit of 65,000 FCFA which will be used to expand her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of damask fabric

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Mariée et mère de six enfants, Madame Mariam  C. est âgée de 37 ans  et vit avec son époux et leurs enfants dans le quartier Wala-Wala de la préfecture de Koutiala (région de Sikasso). 
Pour des raisons sociales, elle n’a pas eu la chance de continuer  les études primaires, elle s’intéressa très tôt aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère. 
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle finit par opter pour l’achat et la vente des fruits et légumes il y a 11 ans.
Cette activité marche bien et procure à Mariam assez de revenus et de notoriété.  
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle  en qualité et  en quantité, augmenter la taille de son activité, elle décida de  faire recours à  l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 4 ans.  
Après  5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe)  tous correctement remboursés,  elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel dont le précédent a été correctement payé.  
Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter, 10 paniers de pomme de terre,  5 paniers de papaye et autres.  Elle s’approvisionne à Sikasso et dans les villages environnants de Koutiala et effectue sa vente au grand marché de Koutiala  à une clientèle constituée  de femmes et d’hommes , au comptant ou à crédit.  Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75.000 FCFA par mois qu’elle envisage utiliser pour  le remboursement des intérêts, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
A married mother of six, Mrs. Mariam C. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and their children in the Wala-Wala borough of the Koutiala Prefecture (Sikasso Region). For social reasons, she was not given the opportunity to complete primary school and from an early age took an interest in revenue-generating activities alongside her mother. After several unsuccessful attempts, she finally took up trading fruit and vegetables some 11 years ago. This activity does well and gives Mariam sufficient income and renown. Four years ago, she decided to call upon the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, to expand her business and satisfy her customers with the quantity and quality of her offerings. After participating in five group loans, all correctly reimbursed, she is now requesting a second personal loan, having repaid in full the preceding one. With this loan she intends to buy: 10 baskets of potatoes, 5 baskets of papayas and other fruit or vegetables. She gets her supplies from Sikasso and villages in the Koutiala area, and sells her goods at the Koutiala main market, to both men and women customers, for cash or credit. She expects to attain average monthly profits of 75,000 FCFA which she will use to reimburse her loan, participate in dealing with family expenses, and invest the remainder in other revenue-generating activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Jenifer's Group

texts.en:
Jenifer A., from the village of Brgy. Darubba, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya, is the 29-year-old leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jenifer, who is single, owns and operates a general store selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jenifer joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Letty

texts.en:
Letty F. is 54 years old and has two children from her marriage to 47-year-old Franklin. One of Letty’s hopes is for her youngest child to go back to school and finish her studies in college. Proceeds from their fishing business managed by her husband are her main source of everything her family needs, especially her children. With the profit from the business, she has been able to purchase appliances for their house. Since they started their own business, their lives have eventually improved. 

For Letty to be able to achieve her dream for her child, she has to grow their business and increase their proceeds. Therefore, she is now requesting a much larger loan through ASHI to finance her business growth plans.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment.

loans.name: Sali

texts.fr:
Madame  Sali  est âgée de 38 ans mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec son mari, sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans l’un des plus célèbres quartier, Koko de la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Pour des raisons sociales, Madame Sali n’a pas eu la chance d’étudier, ce qui explique son intérêt pour  le commerce  auprès de sa mère depuis à bas âge. 
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle s’intéressa finalement  l’achat et la vente d’articles divers  depuis 11 ans, tels les tissus.  
Sali est très bien sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité de ses articles.  
Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle, Sali  a décidé de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il  y a 1 an.  Après  2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement elle est à  son  premier prêt individuel.
Elle compte acheter, des pièces de tissus à Cotonou et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle composée  de femmes et d’ hommes, au comptant ou à crédit.  
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement de son échéance, participer aux charges quotidiennes de la famille et poursuivre son activité avec le reste.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sali is 38 years of age, married and the mother of five children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, the other wife of her husband and their children in Koko, one of the best-known districts of the town of Koutiala (Sikiasso region). For social reasons, Mrs. Sali did not have an opportunity to get an education, which explains her early interest in helping her mother in commerce. After trying several business activities without success, eleven years ago she finally turned to the purchase and resale of various articles such as fabrics. Sali’s business is very popular with customers because of the quality of her goods. In order to expand her activity and satisfy customer demand, a year ago Sali has decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After two joint (group) loans, she is now seeking her first individual loan. She plans to purchase a supply of fabrics in Cotonou. She sells in the town of Koutiala to a customer base composed of both women and men, for cash or in credit. She hopes to achieve a monthly income of 100,000 West African Francs, which she will use to repay her loan, contribute to the everyday family expenses and reinvest the rest into her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing of fabrics (for resale)

loans.name: Kanoni Tweyambe Group Of Kihihi

texts.en:
As it appears, A. Annet has gotten into a “leaps and bounds” business stride selling tea leaves. What has been even more outstanding is the fact that her business only took root one year ago in Kanoni, Kihihi district. She is an entrepreneurial woman with a determined business sense of purpose, intent on setting her own trends.

Annet’s story seems to be an exception to that stereotypical societal rule that has for long held that women hardly succeed in her kind of business. At 29 years old, she seemingly is on the right track. With her monthly profits of 250,000 shillings, this hardworking woman has been able to reach a satisfactory rate in her business operations. Her six children all go to school and her family’s welfare has improved.

Annet’s main drawback has been the inconsistency and unreliability of her suppliers. On several occasions, she has had to make do with less supplies, yet she was inundated with enormous customer demands. With this in mind, she has drawn up plans whereby she wants to cultivate her own tea plantations to be able to redress this discrepancy in her line of work. In her own estimation, this loan will be her tower of support as she drives her dream.

loans.use: To cultivate her own tea plantation

loans.name: Isata

texts.en:
Isatu J. is 52 years old, married with five children.  Her first child is married, the second is in college, and the last three are in primary school.

Isatu is a member of Kiva field partner LAPO SL, and has taken two previous loans,that helped her to expand the inventory of her shop.  Isatu lives in Laka with her entire family, and has a shop very close to her house where she sells provisions.

She is asking for a loan of 2,000,000 Leones to enable her buy more goods for her shop and also to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase provisions for sale.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena D. is 28 years old and a very good member of Kiva partner, ASHI. She is also a very responsible mother to her two children, aged six and seven, both of whom are in primary school. Rowena’s husband is a hired company driver. He is sweet and loving to her and the children. Despite facing poverty and the many adversities it causes, a good relationship with her husband and children is Rowena's inspiration and motivation to pursue her dream of giving her children an improved kind of life worth living for.
Somehow, Rowena wanted to help her husband earn money for their children's future educational expenses until they receive their own bachelor degrees. She joined ASHI in 2008 and has been able to set up a hog-fattening business. She fattens hogs in four months and then sells them, either slaughtered or alive, at the market or in her village. After one year, Rowena realized that her business profits were quite good and therefore she is requesting a loan to grow her hog-fattening business into a piggery in her backyard.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita R., from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon, is 53 years old, married and the mother of seven school-aged children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a specialized retail store selling dried fish in the local community. Engaged in the business for over a year, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Lolita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to invest in expanding the business, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mabula Group

texts.en:
Simon M., a 29-year-old married father of a three-and-a-half-year-old child, has operated a table-top business selling fruits and vegetables since 2000. Working from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily, he is able to make a monthly profit of about $270. To increase his business stock, Simon is requesting his first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He will share this loan with his loan group Mabula, which consists of 11 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

In the picture, Simon is first on the right in the second row.

loans.use: To increase business stock

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella B., a resident of the village of Talakag, Bukidnon, is 43 years old, separated from her spouse, and has one infant. To make a living, Estrella owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Estrella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPF that was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, she is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. Estrella plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya de l’association Horonya est composé de 10  femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 33 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Depuis environ 15 ans, les femmes du groupe font le  commerce d’articles divers tels l’arachide, le riz,  le haricot, les tissus, les savons de toilettes et de lessives, les produits cosmétiques  dans lequel excelle particulièrement Josseline D., etc,  à Tominian. 
Pour l’épanouissement de leurs activités, ces femmes ont décidé de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt Josseline D.,  compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, 6 cartons de parfums  et 20 cartons d’autres petits articles de beauté de  tous genres auprès des grossistes à Bamako. Josseline effectue sa vente à Tominian, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, au comptant en détail et à crédit.
Tandis que Josseline espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 21.000FCFA les autres membres du groupe envisagent obtenir 18.000FCFA.
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses familiales et réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Danaya group of the Horonya association is made up of ten married women from the town of Tominian in Segou, the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families and are on average 33 years old with at least five children. For about 15 years, women in the group have been retailing various items such as peanuts, rice, beans, clothing fabric, toilet and laundry soap, and cosmetic products, which is Josseline D.’s specialty in Tominian. The women decided to call upon the Doro Yiriwaso MFI to help develop their activities. With her part of the loan, Josseline D. intends to buy 6 cartons of perfumes and 20 cartons of various cosmetics from wholesalers in Bamako. She sells her products in Tominian, for the most part to women customers, retail and for cash or credit. Whereas Josseline is hoping for monthly earnings of 21,000 FCFA, the other group members expect to reach 18,000 FCFA. The profits will be used to deal with family expenses and reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetic products

loans.name: Leposo

texts.en:
Leposo K. is a 40-year-old gentleman who is married to Nataana K., and they have three children. Leposo owns a piece of land upon which he has farmed for the past nine years. He also keeps livestock which he fattens and then sells at a profit.

Leposo learned about KADET from other members who had already registered as clients. This will be his second loan with which he is planning to develop large-scale farming for wheat, which does very well in this area, and also buy more beef cattle. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to lease additional land for farming to increase his wheat output.

His future dream is to become the best farmer in his area both in wheat production and livestock keeping. Leposo believes he is hard working and he only needs the resources to attain his goals.

loans.use: To plant more acres of wheat and buy beef cattle for fattening.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djekafo de l’association Miniankaton est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le commerce d’articles divers à Tominian tels, les boissons, les tissus, les pagnes et les bazins. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Miniankaton ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  une année.  Après avoir correctement remboursé le prêt précédent, ce groupe est à son deuxième prêt à l’instar de Kanou D. qui fait l’achat et la vente de pagnes wax. 
Son  prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, à Bamako et à Lomé pour revendre à Tominian et dans les différentes foires, des pièces pagnes wax, à une clientèle constituée généralement de femmes et de quelques hommes, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle  compte réaliser un bénéfice de 20.000FCFA par mois qui permettra d’apporter un appui financier à son époux et  augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique de vente en gros de pagnes wax à Tominian.
texts.en:
The Djekafo group of the Miniankaton association is made up of married women from the town of Tominian in Segou, the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families and are on average 30 years old with at least five children. Women in the group have been retailing various items In Tominian such as beverages, clothing fabric, pagnes (colorful West African cloth) and bazins (traditional West African damask-like dyed cloth). The women from the Djekafo group decided about a year ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit loan programme to increase their activities’ profits. After correctly reimbursing the first group loan, the group is now requesting a second loan. Kanou D. belongs to the group and trades in pagnes wax (a well-known variety of pagnes). Her portion of the loan will be used to buy pagne wax pieces of fabric, bought in Bamako and Lomé for resale in Tominian and various market fairs, for cash or credit, for the most part to women (and also a few men) customers, She is hoping to attain monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA, which will enable her to assist her husband financially and increase her working capital. Her ambition is to open a pagne wax wholesale store in Tominian.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pagnes wax (popular variety of colorful West African cloth)

loans.name: Fayida Group

texts.fr:
Les  5 femmes  qui constituent le groupe Fayida sont toutes mariées. Avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 5 enfants et vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles Bobo dans la ville de Tominian (région de Ségou, république du Mali), elles se sont connues à travers des liens  de voisinages et de parenté. 
Elles exercent presque la même activité  qui est la restauration et l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires.  
Anou Dembélé qui est la présidente du groupe s’est spécialisée dans la restauration. Cette activité lui est très rentable et elle est très sollicitée. 
Ce groupe Fayida est à son deuxième prêt avec l’institution et Anou compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, des sacs de riz et une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires pour la restauration, sur place à Tominian. Anou vend toutes sortes de plats alimentaires dans son restaurant sis en plein cœur de Tominian au bord du goudron. 
Avec une clientèle constituée essentiellement d’élèves maîtres de  l’Institut de Formations de Maîtres (IFM) et de fonctionnaires, Anou espère réaliser un bénéfice de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Anou ambitionne avoir un prêt plus important pour ouvrir un deuxième restaurant.
texts.en:
The five women in the Fayida group are all married. On average they are 32 years old with five children, living in large traditional Bobo families (the Bobo ethnic group is found in Mali and Burkina Faso), in the town of Tominian in the Segou Region of the Republic of Mali. They were acquainted through family ties and as neighbours. They all have practically the same activity which is the restaurant business and trading in culinary condiments. Anou Dembelé is the group’s president and runs a restaurant. This activity provides good income and she is very much in demand. The Fayida group is requesting their second group loan from the institution and Anou intends to use her part to buy - locally in Tominian - bags of rice and a large quantity of culinary condiments for her restaurant business. Anou sells a variety of food preparations in her restaurant located at the roadside in the very centre of Tominian . Her customers are for the most part student schoolteachers from “l’Institut de Formations de Maîtres (IFM)” and public service officials. She hopes to attain monthly profits of 25,000 FCFA which will be used to reimburse the loan and deal with daily family expenses. Anou’s wish is for a larger loan so that she can open a second restaurant.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic ingredients for restaurant business

loans.name: Mwaminifu Group

texts.en:
Suma M., 43 and married with two children, ages 10 and 7, has operated a brick business since 2008. Working from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m., she is able to make a monthly profit of about $147. This will be Suma’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, the first having been used to buy more cement and sand and repaid promptly. She now hopes for a loan to buy still more sand and cement.

Suma will share this loan with her loan Group Mwaminifu, which totals 12 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. In the picture, Suma is in orange, second from left in the last row .

loans.use: To buy more cement and sand

loans.name: Kitwe Twetungure, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Joselyn K. is 43 years old and is married with two children. She operates her fifteen-year-old garment sales business from Rwentuha trading centre. 100,000 Ugandan shillings is the amount this experienced businesswoman makes in a month. This is paltry for a woman with no other form of income.

It is for this reason that Joselyn wants to get this loan to improve her financial prospects. By her own account, the future of her business is promising once she gets this loan. With it she wants to purchase more garments to give her business a new lease of life.
Joselyn belongs to a group who hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more eye-catching stock

loans.name: Kanouya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kanouya de l’association Dounkafa est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans et ont au moins 4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe Kanouya font de la restauration et le commerce d’articles divers. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y'a une année. 
Après le premier prêt solidaire remboursé sans aucune difficulté, ce groupe est à son deuxième prêt.
Bernadette D. est un des membres du groupe qui évolue dans le secteur de la restauration depuis maintenant 10 ans. Elle est très sollicitée, appréciée et enviée grâce à la qualité de ses prestations. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des sacs de céréales et une importante quantité de condiments alimentaires. Elle s’approvisionne sur place et vend dans son restaurant situé aux abords de l’artère principale reliant Tominian à Beninna à une clientèle constituée généralement  de routiers.
Elle espère réaliser tout comme les autres membres du groupe Kanouya    un bénéfice mensuel de 20 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elle  ambitionne avoir un montant  plus élevé pour se ravitaille de condiments en gros à Bamako.
texts.en:
The Kanouya group of the Dounkafa association is made up of married women from the town of Tominian in Segou, the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families and are on average 28 years old with at least four children. Women in the group are in the restaurant business and the trading of various goods. The group members decided about a year ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit loan programme to increase their activities’ profits. After correctly reimbursing the first group loan, the group is now requesting a second loan. Bernadette D. is one of the group’s members who has been in the restaurant business for the past ten years. She is very much in demand, both appreciated and envied due to the quality of her food preparations. She intends to use her part of the loan to buy bags of grain cereals and a large quantity of food condiments. She gets her supplies locally and runs a restaurant close by the main road linking Tominian to Beninna, to mainly truck driver customers. She – as well as the other members of the Kanouva group - is hoping to attain monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA, which will be used to reimburse the loan and deal with daily family expenses. Her ambition is to be granted a larger loan so that she can buy condiments wholesale in Bamako.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients for the restaurant business

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic U. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 29 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Marivic owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products such as viand in the local community. Marivic has been involved in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. Marivic is requesting a new loan, her third, of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Parissi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Parissi de l’association Dori est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 26 ans, au moins 4 enfants et font l’achat et la vente de d’articles divers tels l’arachide,  les condiments alimentaires, les boissons etc. 
Ce groupe est à son deuxième prêt  solidaire après avoir bien remboursé le premier.
Sara D. qui la présidente du groupe Parissi évolue dans l’alimentaire avec l’achat et la vente de boissons. Elle est la représentante de la société Bramali (brasserie du Mali) à Tominian. Elle vend toutes sortes de boissons et cela il y'a environ 10 ans. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter, des casiers de sucreries auprès de sa Société qui produit des boissons. Elle ravitaille les revendeurs et les petits villages environnants de Tominian au comptant très généralement. 
Sara envisage réaliser un bénéfice de 21.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour agrandir l’entreprise.
texts.en:
The group Parissi of the association Dori is composed of married women from the city of Tominian, region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women live in traditional extended families, average 26 years of age, and have least four children.  The women buy and sell a variety of goods, such as peanuts, condiments, beverages, etc. The group members are on their second solidarity loan after having repaid the first one.  Sara D., who is the president of the group, works in the area of foodstuff by buying and selling beverages.  She is the sales representative of the Bramali Company (brewery of Mali) in Tominian.  She has been selling all kinds of drinks for about ten years.  She intends to use her loan for buying cases of soft drinks from the Company, which produces beverages.  Generally accepting cash, she resupplies retailers and the villages surrounding Tominian. Sara envisions making a profit of 21,000 francs CFA per month that will be used to expand her enterprise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying soft drinks

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabali de l’association Djekadi est composé de 10 femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 31 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe Sabali font entre autres le commerce d’articles divers tels le savon, le poisson, les céréales, les condiments alimentaires, les articles de boutique, la restauration etc, il y’a environ 10 ans. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Sabali de l’association Djekadi ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année. 
La présidente du groupe Mougnoussi Sangaré évolue dans le commerce général avec sa boutique dénommée « diverma » où on y trouve du savon, des articles de fêtes, des produits ménagers et d’autres articles  divers de boutique. 
Elle compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, des paquets de différents produits divers auprès de grossistes à San et de Bamako pour revendre en détail, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit, à Tominian à une clientèle riche et variée. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice de 22500FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
The group Sabali of the association Djekadi is composed of ten married women of the city of Tominian, region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women live in traditional families, average 31 years of age, and have least four children.  For about ten years, the women do commerce in a variety of items, such as soap, fish, grains, condiments, and store products, and they work in food catering, etc. To make their businesses profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about a year ago.  The group's president Mougnoussi Sangaré is working in general commerce with her store called "Diverma", where you can find soap, holiday items, household products, and various other store goods.  She plans on using her loan to buy packets of different products from wholesalers in San and from Bamako.  These goods will be sold retail, for cash and sometimes on credit, in Tominian, to a rich and varied customer base.  Mougnoussi envisions making a profit of 22,500 francs CFA per month that will be used to expand her store.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Sinignèssigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèssigui de l’association Badenya est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 31 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le  commerce d’articles divers tels le poisson fumé, les tissus, les savons, les céréales etc,  il y’a environ 10 ans. 
Massaran Kamaté est un des membres qui fait l’achat et la vente de poissons fumés.
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Sinignèssigui de l’association Badenya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a un an.     
Le prêt actuel  de Massaran sera utilisé pour acheter, des colis de poissons fumés à partir de la cinquième région administrative du Mali, Mopti. Massaran vend en gros, en détail au comptant et à crédit à Tominian à une clientèle composée de consommateurs et de revendeurs.   
 Les membres du groupe Sinignèssigui comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Massaran Kamaté ambitionne avoir un financement important pour ouvrir une poissonnerie à Tominian.
texts.en:
The group Sinignèssigui of the association Badenya is composed of married women from the city Tominian, region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women live in traditional families, average 31 years of age, and have at least six children.  The women have been doing commerce for about ten years in a variety of items, such as smoked fish, cloth, soaps, grains, etc.  Massaran Kamaté is one of the members who buys and sells smoked fish.  To make their businesses profitable, the group members decided a year ago to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  Massaran's current loan will be used to buy packages of smoked fish from the 5th administrative region of Mali, Mopti.  Accepting cash or credit, she sells wholesale and retail to a customer base composed of consumers and retailers in Tominian.  The group members each plan on making a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used for repaying the loan interest and covering typical family expenses.  Massaran Kamaté has the ambition to obtain significant financing for opening a fish store in Tominian.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying smoked fish

loans.name: Adpat N°2 Group

texts.fr:
L’Association pour le Développement des Parcelles Assainies de Thiès (ADPAT) est un groupement mixte composé de personnes habitantes toutes dans un même quartier  les  Parcelles Assainies, un quartier très grand à Thiès. Elle a été créée en 2003 sous l’influence d’un groupe de femmes  qui étaient en tontine (système de financement tournant dans lequel chaque membre cotise périodiquement une somme convenue et qu’on verse à tour de rôle aux différents membres). Cependant, les membres sont animés d’un même objectif qui est de créer la solidarité et de développer leur cher quartier les Parcelles Assainies.   
  L’association est actuellement dirigée par Madame Diallé Ndir, une  dame très engagée et qui connait bien la culture associative.  Elle est scindée auprès de U-IMCEC en 9 sous groupements avec un président et un trésorier pour chaque sous groupe afin de les faire profiter de ses services.
Pour ADPAT N°2, Madame Fatimata Nadia Dème est la présidente. Née en 1963, Madame Fatimata Nadia Dème est couturière depuis plus de 10 ans. Elle s’est investie depuis un certain temps dans le commerce de divers produits à savoir tissus…etc. En d’autres  termes, Madame Dème s’intéresse dans presque toutes les activités de développement de son quartier. Elle est présentement la présidente du comité de gestion au niveau du collège de son quartier. Cependant avec l’argent demandé, elle prévoit de s’approvisionner en marchandises pour son commerce comme toutes ses sœurs avec lesquelles elle partage le sous groupe. 
Il s’agit entre autre de Madame Aby K. âgée de 63 ans et vendeuse de tissus, savon et oignons, Madame Maguette Gueye née en 1957 et qui vend de l’huile, Niébé ou haricot local, et des poissons séchés, Madame Ramatoulaye N. 22 ans et vendeuse de beignets et petit déjeuner et Madame Fatou N. qui vend des chaussures, sacs et des habits…
texts.en:
ADPAT, which stands for The Association for the Development of Parcelles Assainies (one of the large urban districts of Dakar) is a group of women who originally formed in 2003 as a “tontine” – a group financing system in which everyone makes periodic contributions, the funds thus raised being lent to each member in turn. They all share the desire to improve their beloved neighborhood, Parcelles Assainies. Today, the Association is directed by Mme. Dialle Ndir, an involved, experienced leader and community organizer. Under the auspices of U-IMCEC, The Association is divided into 9 sub-groups, each with a president and treasurer. The president of ADPAT N°2 is Mme. Fatimata Nadia Dème, who was born in 1963. She has worked as a seamstress for more than 10 years. For some time she has also sold a variety of goods, notably cloth. She is active in almost all development activities in her neighborhood. She is president of the board of the local middle school. With the loan money, she plans to purchase merchandise for her business, like all of her “sisters” in the subgroup. Other members include Mme. Aby K., aged 63, who sells cloth, soap and onions; Mme. Maguette Gueye, born in 1957, who sells oil, dried fish and Niébé, a type of kidney bean; Mme. Ramatoulaye N., ade 22, who sells fritters and breakfast foods, and Mme. Fatou N. who sells shoes, purses and clothing.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods for resale

loans.name: Siyawan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Siyawan de l’association Parisi est composé 6 de femmes   mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 25 ans et au moins 5 enfants. 
Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels, les habillements, les condiments alimentaires et les céréales qui  est le domaine de Didia D., très sollicitée et appréciée à Tominian par sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses articles.
Le prêt de Didia sera utilisé pour acheter,  20 sacs d’arachide par semaine dans les foires environnantes de Seoulasso et  de San. Elle effectue sa vente, en gros, au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs.
Les membres du groupe Siyawan comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 20.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Parisi association's Siyawan group is made up of six married women from the town of Tominian, in the Ségou region, the fourth administrative district in the Republic of Mali. All six women live in traditional families and are on average 25 years old, with at least 5 children. They met through neighborhood and family connections and sell various goods such as clothing, spices and grains, which is the domain of Didia D., very sought after and appreciated by her customers in Tominian for the quality of her goods. Didia's loan will be used to buy 20 sacks of peanuts each week in the markets around Seoulasso and San. She makes her sales wholesale, in cash, retail and credit to a customer base made up of retailers and consumers. The members of the Siyawan group calculate that they will each turn a monthly profit of 20,000 CFA francs, which will be used for the repayment of the loan's interest and daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying peanuts

loans.name: Kisiita Development Group Of Mubende

texts.en:
At the young age of 24 years, N. Moses is a fledgling produce sales business trend-setter whose example is bound to stand out as a benchmark for other youth in his home area of Kisiita in Mubende district. Many youths in his home area preoccupy themselves in self-destructive activities like drinking.

Moses has subsisted on a produce sales business for four years. With his hard work, he has managed to take firm root and, in a week, he apparently makes 50,000 shillings.

With his monthly savings, Moses has managed to diversify his small business. This has, however, not come easy as he has had to grapple with many adversities such as the unpredictable weather patterns which, for the most part, mean he has fewer supplies from farmers.

Moses’ dream is to build his own produce stalls and a store to keep his surplus goods. With this loan he hopes to implement this.

loans.use: To purchase more produce to sell

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward ole N. is 24 years old. He is married to Esther N. and the father of two children, aged 6 months and 3 years.

Edward has been farming for the last five years. His farm is in a productive area. Most of his customers are wholesalers from the city who come to buy his produce and then sell it to city residents.

Edward learned about KADET through an awareness program run by KADET staff in his area. This will be his second loan, which he plans to use as follows: 30,000 KES for wheat farming and 20,000 KES to buy sheep for fattening to sell later at a profit. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for his wheat.

Edward's future dream is to become a large scale farmer and attain financial independence.  Edward is a young and energetic man who can do more if supported financially.

loans.use: To plant more acres of wheat and buy sheep for fattening and resale

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario P. is from the village of Galas. She is 64 years old, widowed, and has 3 adult-aged children. Rosario owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Rosario has been involved in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP per month from it.

In 2006, Rosario joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosario has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosario is requesting a new loan, her 9th, for 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase construction materials for a bathroom. She plans to have a well-sanitized waste disposal system for the family to use. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for a bathroom

loans.name: Mukama Yassinga Goup Of Mukono Group

texts.en:
His business story has a checkered career of ups and downs since he began it two years ago in Kirinya, Mukono district. The dawn of 2010 promised to open new horizons for his snack business (fruit and vegetables) but nothing has significantly improved since. His business enterprise, though replete with losses, has remained afloat thanks to his resilient nature.

This is the story of M. Emmanuel, a 25-year-old married father of one child. If his financial prospects are to improve, he needs help because, based on the 119,000 shillings he makes in a week, his business future may not be that secure after all. A loan, he figures, will go a long way in helping him expand his snack business.

loans.use: To expand his snack business by buying more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Shangilieni Group

texts.fr:
Chikwanine C. C.  est présidente du groupe de crédit  Shangilieni, elle lève sa main sur la photo, cliente au 15e cycle, âgée de 45 ans, veuve, mère de 7 enfants et tous étudient dans des écoles  normales . Il ya 5 ans que son mari est décedé (en 2005) suite à une courte maladie. Pendant ces 5 ans, elle supporte seule la charge de ses enfants orphelins. Cette charge pèse lourdement  sur croissance rapide de son business.  
Son business est une minu Quincaillèrie  exposée sur étallage public du marché secteur de Himbi Alanine . Il y a 8 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité de muni Quincaillerie.
Elle  a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari avant qu’il décède. son capital initial était de 200$, mais avec la mort de son mari, elle a connu une perturbation totale, et ses activites ont grandement chuté. 
Avec  le crédit de  l’IMF Hekima,  Chikwanine C. C.  souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achétant 10 roulot des fils électriques de valeur de 500$,  6 dizaines des  Scies de valeur de  200$.
 Chikwanine C. C. vend également des Fanta, bièrres Primus  à son domicile pour accroitre son revenu et repondre aux petites urgences et nécessités de menage.
Dans l’avenir, elle planifie de chercher un dépôt d’exposition de ses produits de quincaillèrie sur le boulevard  principal de l’axe  Katindo, enfin d’etre plus competitive dans ce business et se créer des bonnes relations d’affaires avec les constructeurs et grands commerçants de la ville. 
Et plus tard construire une petite boutique pour encadrer ses enfants à la maison et maximiser des grands bénéfices  additionnels en dehors de ses activités de quincaillèrie. 
 Chikwanine C. C. rémércie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grace à ces crédits, elle a parvenu à construire une maison en planche de 10 chambres, qu’elle met à location. Les recettes de loyer de cette maison lui permet  de subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants.
En plus, Chikwanine C. C.  a aisement retrouvé le soulagement et l’équilibre  économique grace aux crédits de Hekima, après la mort de son mari.Actuellement son business evolue positivement. Le groupe de crédit  Shangilieni  est  composé de 16 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Chikwanine C. C. is the president of the lending group Shangilieni.  (Her hand is raised in the photo.)  She is a 15th cycle client and is 45 years old, a widow, and the mother of seven children, who are all studying in écoles normales (post-secondary colleges).  Five years ago (in 2005), her husband died after a brief illness.  During these five years, she alone has been supporting her orphaned children.  This responsibility weighs heavily upon the rapid growth of her business.  Her business is a mini hardware store displaying goods openly at the market in the Himbi Alanine sector.  She has been in this business for eight years.  She started her small business with her own funds received from her husband following his death.  The initial capital amounted to $200. But with her husband's death, she experienced such upheaval, and her work tumbled. C., with the loan from the micro-finance institution Hekima, wishes to increase her sales by buying ten rolls of electrical wire valued at $500 and six dozen saws valued at $200.  She also sells Fanta and Primus beers out of her home in order to increase her income, to respond to minor emergencies, and to cover household necessities.  In the future, C. plans to find an outlet for her hardware goods to display on the main boulevard of the Katindo line.  She can then be more competitive in this business and engender good business connections with the builders and major merchants of the city.  Later on, she wishes to construct a small shop at home to take care of her children and to maximize large profits in additional to those from the hardware store. C. thanks the IMF Hekima for the loans she receives without the need for any collateral at all.  Thanks to these loans, she managed to build a 10-room house made of boards that she rents out.  The rental income from this house enables her to meet the needs of her children. In addition, C. has found relief with ease and has gained financial stability, thanks to Hekima loans following her husband's death.  Currently, her business is advancing.  The Shangilieni lending group is composed of sixteen members, most of whom are women.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ten rolls of electrical wire and six dozen saws

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a camera

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase mulches and farm tools

loans.name: Rohina

texts.en: Rohina is the daughter of M. H.. She lives in the 15th district of Kabul and is married with four children. She wants to repair her house to be able to live comfortably. She has requested an individual loan of 40,000 AFN to buy construction materials. She says that she is confident that she will make all her repayments on time. She wants to thanks all lenders of Kiva and AFS in Afghanistan.

loans.use: buy construction materials

loans.name: Lasmin

texts.pt:
Lasmin L. Comé nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, Fronteira com a vizinha Suazilândia a oeste da província de Maputo, tem 29 anos de idade vive maritalmente é mãe de 2 filhos de idades compreendidas entre os 9 e 12 anos, ambos vão a escola. Fez a 8ª classe e interrompe os estudos devido a gravidez, vive na casa própria com a sua família.


Nunca saiu da sua terra natal. Vive maritalmente, trabalha no conselho Municipal da vila de Namaacha como auxiliar faz cerca de 8horas por dia e tem um salário de mensal de 2080,00mt que aplica nas dispersas da casa. Conta com ajuda do seu marido que também trabalha na mesma instituição e consegue por mês poupar 1.000.00mt 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através dos seus colegas que são nossos clientes. Este e seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção nomeadamente (cimento, barrotes e chapas de zinco) para dar continuidade  da  obra na sua residência.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder novos créditos. No futuro gostaria de pedir novos empréstimos para dar continuidade da sua obra.
texts.en:
Lasmin L. Comé was born in Namaacha District, which is on the border with Swaziland and west of Maputo District. She is 29 years old, is married and has 2 children between 9 and 12 years old. Both children go to school. Lasmin finished eighth grade but dropped out of school due to pregnancy. She lives in her own house with her family. Lasmin has never left her hometown. She is married and is an employee of the Namaacha city council. She works about 8 hours a day and has a monthly salary of 2,080 meticais, which she uses for household expenses. She counts on the help of her husband, who works for the same employer and manages to save 1,000 meticais per month. She has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through some colleagues who are also our customers. This is Lasmin's first loan with Hluvuku. She is asking for 10,000 meticais, which she will use to buy construction materials, namely cement, beams and zinc sheets, to continue work on her house. She promises to pay off this loan on time so she can take out more loans. In the future she would like to ask for more loans to finish building her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cement, beams and zinc sheets

loans.name: Noor Aqa Group

texts.en:
Marina is a member of the Noor Aqa group. She lives in the 11th district of Kabul. She is 37 years old and married with two children.

Marina has a business doing embroidery work and is quite popular in her neighborhood. People like her style of work and bring cloth to her so that she can create great designs in embroidery work for them.

Marina would like to receive a loan in order to purchase the required materials for her business to progress well and to increase. She hopes for a bright future for her children and to have a shop to work in, instead of working from her house. Marina is really happy about this effective loan process.

loans.use: purchase the required materials for her business

loans.name: Deolinda

texts.pt:
Deolinda M. B., nasceu no distrito de zavala, província de inhambane sul de Moçambique. Tem 48 anos de idade vive maritalmente e mãe de 10 filhos com idades compreendidas os entre os 12 a 35 anos, somente os 5 mais novos e que vão a escola. Faz a 4 classe e teve que interromper quando seu pai perde a vida. Vive na casa própria com sua família e não responsabiliza se por ninguém.

Sai de inhambane para namaacha quando seu esposo e transferido em emisao de serviço onde veio fixar sua casa onde vivem ate então. Tem um negocio próprio a mais de 20 anos, não tem empregados conta somente com ajuda do seu marido, Vende mais farinha de milho, tomate e cebola onde consegue um rendimento de 5.000.00mt e aplica na sua obra. Não consegue poupar nenhum valor e conta com ajuda do seu marido que e pensionista.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outras instituições, conhece a hluvuku através da amiga que e nossa cliente, este e o segundo empréstimo na hluvuku e primeiro com kiva no valor de 15.000.00mt com qual pretende comprar produtos de primeira necessidade aumentando assim o volume do seu stock.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a mais outros. Sonha ter uma mercearia própria. Vai solicitar mais empréstimos para habitação da sua casa.
texts.en:
Deolinda M. B. was born in the district of Zavala, Inhambane Province, in southern Mozambique. She is 48 years old and married, with 10 children between the ages of 12 and 25. Only the five youngest go to school. She finished fourth grade but had to stop when her father passed away. She lives in her own house with her family, and is not financially responsible for anyone else. She moved from Inhambane to Namaacha when her husband was transferred, and they set up a new home where they still live today. She's had her own business for more than 20 years. She doesn't have employees, and relies on her husband for assistance. She sells cornmeal, tomatoes, and onions, and brings in about 5000 meticals, which she reinvests in her business. She is not able to save anything and depends on her husband's pension. She's never had loans with other institutions. She heard about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client. This is her second loan with Hluvuku and her first with Kiva. She is requesting 15,000 meticals to buy essentials and increase the amount of stock she can carry. She's committed to paying this loan off on time so that she'll be eligible for others in the future. Her dream is to have her own shop, and will request additional loans to prepare a space in her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cornmeal, tomatoes, onions, and other products

loans.name: Boureima

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boureima Traoré est un homme marié de 30 ans et sans enfant. Il vit avec sa femme à Bougouni ville (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) dans le quartier Torakabougou.
Après l’école coranique, il est resté longtemps sans emploi.
C’est dans le souci de s’insérer dans la vie économique qu’il  décida d’apprendre auprès de son ami,  le commerce notamment l’achat et la vente des chaussures et vêtements.
Avec 6 années expériences, il maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité à Bougouni.
Dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, il rejoint le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter, des  paires de chaussures  et des vêtements de différentes sortes et qualités.
Il s’approvisionne à Lomé et à Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali) et effectue ses ventes dans sa boutique, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et femmes. 
Les fêtes religieuses et les grandes cérémonies (baptême, mariages) sont les périodes où les ventes de ses articles sont intenses.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA qui lui permettra de subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans ses activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Boureima Traoré is a 30-year-old married man who has no children.  He lives with his wife in Bougouni City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali), in the Torakabougou district.  Following Koranic school, he was without employment for quite a while.  Wanting to take part in the working world, he decided to learn commerce from his friend, especially the buying and selling of shoes and clothing. With six years of experience, Boureima has a command of his business and is highly sought-after in Bougouni.  With regard to improving his business, he joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  With this loan, he intends to buy pairs of shoes and some clothing of all different types and qualities.  He stocks up in Lomé and in Bamako (capital of Mali).  And he makes his sales out of his store to a customer base composed of men and women.  Religious festivals and major ceremonies (baptisms, marriages) are the times when his sales are intense.  With this loan, Boureima plans on making a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA that will enable him to cover family expenses and to reinvest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying shoes and clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam S. est une femme mariée de 34 ans et mère de 4 enfants qui vit dans une famille monogame avec son mari et leurs enfants  dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni (troisième région du Mali). 
Elle a vite abandonné l’école au profit des activités génératrices de revenus notamment la vente des bananes. Elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 8 ans, ce qui explique sa maîtrise dans ce domaine d’activité. 
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 5 ans. Après deux prêts correctement remboursés, elle est à son troisième qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de bananes. Elle s'approvisionne dans la commune de Sido (située à 25 kilomètres de Bougouni) et dans les villages environnants. Elle effectue sa vente dans les différents quartiers et au marché de Bougouni.
Elle envisage  réaliser  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour ressoude certaines dépenses familiales et  acheter un lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam S. is a 34-year-old married woman and the mother of four children who live in a monogamous family with her husband and their children in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni (3rd region of Mali).  She soon dropped out of school in favor of income-generating work, especially selling bananas.  She has been in this business for eight years, which explains her command of this business sector.  In order to satisfy her customers, Mariam decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago.  After two loans, properly repaid, she is now on her third loan, which will be used for buying a large quantity of bananas.  She stocks up in the community of Sido (located 25 km from Bougouni) and in the surrounding villages.  She makes her sales in the various districts and at the Bougouni market. With this loan, Mariam envisions making a monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used for resolving certain family expenses and for buying a residential plot of land.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bananas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more dry gin, powder, candles, etc., to  sell

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou Konaté est un homme marié de 37 ans et père de 2 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans la maison de son père à Bougouni dans le quartier Niébala.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
Depuis 12 ans il mène l’activité de fabrication de marmites. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son père.
Monsieur Seydou Konaté à une maîtrise  de son activité qui lui est rentable.
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers un autre client, il décida de collaborer avec l’institution. Il est à son premier prêt individuel et compte acheter, 12 tas aluminium et 10 sacs de charbon  de bois.Il s'approvisionne  sur place et vend sa production sur place  à Bougouni, dans les villages environnants, au marché et à dans les foires hebdomadaires.  La plupart de ses clients sont des femmes.
Monsieur Seydou Konaté compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qu’il compte utiliser pour agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou Konaté is a married man, who is 37 years old and father to two children. He lives with his wife and children in his father's house in Bougouni in the Niébala district. Since he did not go to modern school, he began his income-generating activities at an early age. For the past twelve years he has had a business making cooking pots. He learned this business from his father. Mr. Seydou Konaté has mastered his business and it is profitable for him. Having got to know Soro Yiriwaso through another customer, he decided to collaborate with the institution. He is on his first individual loan and plans to buy 12 loads of aluminium and ten bags of charcoal. He gets his supplies locally and also sells what he makes locally in Bougouni, as well as in neighboring villages, on the market and at weekly fairs. The majority of his customers are women. Mr. Seydou Konaté estimates that he will make a monthly profit of 35,000FCFA which he is planning to use to expand his business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of aluminium

loans.name: Nyabugando Tukwatanise, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
T. Africana is a reserved 40-year-old married father of three children. He has been operating his butchery business from Nyabugando Trading Centre in Ntungamo district for over fifteen years. He buys cows and goats which he slaughters and gets meat ready for selling.

Africana’s business has grown to the extent that he has been able to educate all three of his children. He reveals he makes, in a month, close to 200,000 shillings. He also makes some additional income through selling firewood. His future plans are to expand his business by opening up another branch.

loans.use: To buy good quality animals for beef

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: Joan is a 25-year-old single mother to one child aged one year. She lives in Hoima, Uganda where she operates a clothing shop. She looks after her child and together they reside in a rented house. She sells clothes for men and women, bags, and shoes. She has been operating the clothing business for 3 years now. She has come far; having started selling clothes in the Central Market in an open area, she now has a shop. She dreams of constructing her own residential house and driving a car one day. This is her first loan from Hofokam and she intends to use the funds for buying clothes, shoes and bags for reselling.

loans.use: buying clothes, shoes and bags for reselling.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.pt:
Carlos A. C. nasceu na província de Inhambane sul de Moçambique, tem 40 anos de idade, vive maritalmente é pais de 5 filhos com idades compriendida entre os 2 aos 18 anos, quatro vão a escola. Fez a 3ª classe e não continuou devido a guerra e a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com sua família e responsabiliza se pelo seu sobrinho que vive com ele.

Sai de Inhambane para Maputo quando foi incorporado no serviço militar obrigatório aos seus 18 anos de idade, 5 anos depois foi desmobilizado e muda se para o Distrito de Namaacha Fronteira com reino Suazi alegando que ia visitar sua tia e fixa sua residência onde vive ate então. Hoje tem um negócio próprio a mais de 10 anos vende potes (panelas de alumínio), não tem horário fixo de trabalho porque vende por encomendas na suazilândia e tem viajado 2 vezes para conscidir com o período de pagamnto da pensão dos idosos, não tem empregados mas conta com ajuda da sua esposa.


Este e o quinto empréstimo de Carlos na hluvuku e segundo com kiva. Os três primeiros no valor de (3.000.00mt, 2.500.00mt, 6.500.00mt e 8.500.00mt) foram usados para compra de potes para revenda e este ultimo de 9.000.00mt será destinado para a mesma finalidade.

Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo determinado e pedir um novo empréstimo para começar com a costrução da sua obra.
texts.en:
Carlos A. C. was born in the province of Inhambane in southern Mozambique. He is 40 years old, married, and has five children between the ages of 2 and 18. Four of them attend school. He finished third grade but had to leave school because of his family's difficult economic circumstances. He lives in his own house with his family and also supports his nephew, who lives with him. He moved from Inhambane to Maputo when he joined to military at 18 to fulfill his obligatory service. Five years later he was discharged and went to the district of Namaacha on the border with Swaziland, saying he was going to visit his aunt, and ended up settling down and still lives there today. Today he's owned his own business selling aluminum pots and pans for more than 10 years. He has a flexible schedule because he sells by special order in Swaziland, and has made two trips to coincide with pension payments. This is Carlos's fifth loan with Hluvuku and his second with Kiva. His first four, in the amounts of 3000, 2500, and 6500, and 8500 meticals, were used to buy sheet metal for resale; he will use this 9000-metical loan for the same purpose. He is confident that he will be able to pay the loan back early and request a new loan to start building a house.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase aluminum cookware to sell

loans.name: Atakola Women's Group Of Jinja

texts.en:
It’s now a decade since 48-year-old affable and focused N. Mayimuna painstakingly began her produce-selling business in Luzinga, Jinja. She has not fared badly, either, as her business has enabled her to educate her five children to secondary school and university level.

Mayimuna has, for the most part, been selling maize, a favorite among many traders in her area of operation. Before she took root in this business, she was doing odd jobs – mostly animal husbandry and selling pancakes. It’s from selling pancakes and selling animals that she got enough capital to start her own business.

Mayimuna has got into a steady and dependable business stride now and she now makes 50,000 shillings per week. With this loan, her sense of optimism is sky high that she will be able to buy additional maize for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more maize for her shop
